item.title: Currently Reading: June 2023
item.author: fqaouwsst@mozmail.com (Mackenzie Fletcher)
item.description: This month I’ll be travelling to Israel, Egypt and Greece before jetting off to Thailand at the end of the month. This means that I may not have a ton of time for reading depending on how long I’ll be out each day and able to stand the sweltering heat. However, I am currently in the middle of a few books. My general goals with reading this year centred around language learning - namely Spanish and French.

item.title: Are simplified language texts worth reading in language learning? - Western Philsophy in Simple Spanish by Olly Richards
item.author: fqaouwsst@mozmail.com (Mackenzie Fletcher)
item.description: In my quest to learn Spanish, and my continued attempts to maintain my French, have led me to the ‘input method’ of language learning. According to this, the primary thing which determines a language learners command of the language is the amount of comprehensible, high-quality input which they get. Naturally, it can be very difficult when first starting a language to understand anything, let alone native-level media on subjects that you’d be interested in.

item.title: The Grand Chessboard of 1997; Or, The World According to America
item.author: fqaouwsst@mozmail.com (Mackenzie Fletcher)
item.description: The Grand Chessboard by Zbigniew Brzeziński explores the world according to America (at least, in 1997.) Brzeziński was a Polish-born political analyst with no shortage of high-profile roles on his resume, serving as a counsellor to Johnson from ‘66-68 and National Security Advisor from ‘77-81 under Carter. The Grand Chessboard presents Brzeziński’s own geopolitical analysis of the world and its various key ‘pieces’ to the American Imperial puzzle. Thus, it particularly focuses on Europe (particularly France and Germany), Russia, the Caucasus, and China in their geopolitical contexts.
